harmonic functions

Let 1≤p<∞1 \leq p < \infty1≤p<∞ and let U(z)U\p{z}U(z) be a harmonic function on the complex plane C\CC such that

∬R×R∣U(x+iy)∣p dx dy<∞.\iint_{\R \times \R} \abs{U\p{x + iy}}^p \,\diff{x} \,\diff{y} < \infty.∬R×R​∣U(x+iy)∣pdxdy<∞.

Prove U(z)=0U\p{z} = 0U(z)=0 for all z=x+iy∈Cz = x + iy \in \Cz=x+iy∈C.
Solution.

Let qqq be such that 1p+1q=1\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1p1​+q1​=1. Since UUU is harmonic everywhere, we may apply the mean value property on any B(z,R)B\p{z, R}B(z,R) with R>0R > 0R>0 to get

∣U(z)∣=∣1πR2∫B(z,R)U(w) dA∣≤1πR2∫B(z,R)∣U(w)∣ dA≤∥U∥LpπR2∥χB(z,R)∥Lq≤∥U∥LpπR2m(B(z,R))1/q=∥U∥LpπR2π1/qR2/q=∥U∥Lpπ1−(1/q)(R2)1−(1/q)=∥U∥Lpπ1/pR2/p,\begin{aligned} \abs{U\p{z}} = \abs{\frac{1}{\pi R^2} \int_{B\p{z,R}} U\p{w} \,\diff{A}} &\leq \frac{1}{\pi R^2} \int_{B\p{z,R}} \abs{U\p{w}} \,\diff{A} \\ &\leq \frac{\norm{U}_{L^p}}{\pi R^2} \norm{\chi_{B\p{z,R}}}_{L^q} \\ &\leq \frac{\norm{U}_{L^p}}{\pi R^2} m\p{B\p{z, R}}^{1/q} \\ &= \frac{\norm{U}_{L^p}}{\pi R^2} \pi^{1/q} R^{2/q} \\ &= \frac{\norm{U}_{L^p}}{\pi^{1-\p{1/q}} \p{R^2}^{1-\p{1/q}}} \\ &= \frac{\norm{U}_{L^p}}{\pi^{1/p} R^{2/p}}, \end{aligned}∣U(z)∣=∣∣​πR21​∫B(z,R)​U(w)dA∣∣​​≤πR21​∫B(z,R)​∣U(w)∣dA≤πR2∥U∥Lp​​∥∥​χB(z,R)​∥∥​Lq​≤πR2∥U∥Lp​​m(B(z,R))1/q=πR2∥U∥Lp​​π1/qR2/q=π1−(1/q)(R2)1−(1/q)∥U∥Lp​​=π1/pR2/p∥U∥Lp​​,​

which tends to 000 as R→∞R \to \inftyR→∞, since p≠∞p \neq \inftyp=∞. Thus, as zzz was arbitrary, we have U(z)=0U\p{z} = 0U(z)=0 everywhere.
